column3: early 20th century; earliest use found in Flight International
early 17th century: from Tupi, imitative of its cry
early 19th century; earliest use found in The Mechanics' Magazine
Middle English: via Old French from Latin alienus ‰Û÷belonging to another‰Ûª, from alius ‰Û÷other‰Ûª
early 18th century: from modern Latin androides, from andro- + -oid

1960s; earliest use found in Ursula Le Guin (b. 1929), writer of science fiction and fantasy. Shortened from answerable, with suffix substitution, so called to contrast with wave-based communication technologies (such as radio) which are not answerable over interstellar distances within any useful period of time
mid 19th century; earliest use found in Thomas Carlyle (1795‰ÛÒ1881), author, biographer, and historian. From any + when
Old English b€Òam ‰Û÷tree, beam‰Ûª, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch boom and German Baum
1960s; earliest use found in Proceedings of the AFIPS Conference
Old English b€t, of Germanic origin
late 19th century (originally US): abbreviation of confidence, as in confidence trick
mid 17th century: from Latin, neuter of continuus (see continuous)

Old English crÌ_ft ‰Û÷strength, skill‰Ûª, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch kracht, German Kraft, and Swedish kraft ‰Û÷strength‰Ûª. craft (sense 3 of the noun), originally in the expression small craft ‰Û÷small trading vessels‰Ûª, may be elliptical, referring to vessels requiring a small amount of ‰Û÷craft‰Ûª or skill to handle, as opposed to large ocean-going ships

mid 16th century (originally in the senses ‰Û÷belief‰Ûª, ‰Û÷credibility‰Ûª): from French crÌ©dit, probably via Italian credito from Latin creditum, neuter past participle of credere ‰Û÷believe, trust‰Ûª
late 17th century: from Dutch kruiser, from kruisen (see cruise)
1960s: invented by the scriptwriter Terry Nation ( 1930‰ÛÒ97)
late Middle English (in dimension (sense 1 of the noun)): via Old French from Latin dimensio(n-), from dimetiri ‰Û÷measure out‰Ûª. dimension (sense 2 of the noun) dates from the 1920s
1949: coined by George Orwell in his novel Nineteen Eighty-Four
late 16th century; earliest use found in Huloets Dictionary. From earth + -like
Middle English (in an earlier sense). In some forms from earth + man. In some forms from the genitive of earth + man

mid 19th century; earliest use found in Elizabeth Barrett Browning (1806‰ÛÒ1861), poet and writer. From earth + side. With use as adverb compare slightly earlier stateside. With use as adjective compare earlier stateside
mid 19th century (in an earlier sense). From earth + woman, after earthman
early 20th century: from Greek empatheia (from em- ‰Û÷in‰Ûª + pathos ‰Û÷feeling‰Ûª) translating German EinfÌ_hlung

late Middle English (in the sense ‰Û÷unreal‰Ûª): from Old French fantastique, via medieval Latin from Greek phantastikos, from phantazein ‰Û÷make visible‰Ûª, phantazesthai ‰Û÷have visions, imagine‰Ûª, from phantos ‰Û÷visible‰Ûª (related to phainein ‰Û÷to show‰Ûª). From the 16th to the 19th centuries the Latinized spelling phantastic was also used

late Middle English: from Old French fantasie, via Latin from Greek phantasia ‰Û÷imagination, appearance‰Ûª, later ‰Û÷phantom‰Ûª, from phantazein ‰Û÷make visible‰Ûª. From the 16th to the 19th centuries the Latinized spelling phantasy was also used
1940s (originally US): blend of fan and magazine
1930s; earliest use found in Aldous Huxley (1894‰ÛÒ1963), writer. From feel + -y, after movie
Old English fen(n), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch veen and German Fenn
1950s. Probably originally a transmission error for folk
1980s; earliest use found in Associated Press Newswire. From filk + -er
1980s; earliest use found in The San Francisco Chronicle. From filk + -ing
late Middle English: frequentative of flit
1960s; earliest use found in Frederik Pohl (1919‰ÛÒ2013), writer of science fiction
late 19th century (originally in nautical use): probably from French gÌ¢chette ‰Û÷lock mechanism‰Ûª or from the French dialect word gagÌ©e ‰Û÷tool‰Ûª
mid 19th century: from Greek galaktias (variant of galaxias ‰Û÷galaxy‰Ûª) + -ic
Old English gÌ_t, geat, plural gatu, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch gat ‰Û÷gap, hole, breach‰Ûª
mid 19th century: perhaps an abbreviation of Jesus
Middle English: via Old French from Latin generatio(n-), from the verb generare (see generate)
1950s; earliest use found in New Worlds Science Fiction
1950s; earliest use found in Astounding Science Fiction. From genetic + engineer, after genetic engineering
early 19th century: French, literally ‰Û÷a kind‰Ûª (see gender)
mid 16th century: the Greek and Roman poets' name for the first period of history, when the human race lived in an ideal state
1960s: a word invented by Robert Heinlein (1907‰ÛÒ88), American author
1980s: probably a blend of hologram and deck, popularized by the television series Star Trek: the Next Generation (1987‰ÛÒ94)
Middle English: via Old French from Latin horror, from horrere ‰Û÷tremble, shudder‰Ûª (see horrid)
1940s; earliest use found in Astounding Science Fiction
early 16th century (in the sense ‰Û÷be moved or thrown with a sudden jerk‰Ûª): probably imitative of the sound of feet coming into contact with the ground

Old English l€Òoht, l€Çht (noun and adjective), l€Çhtan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch licht and German Licht, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek leukos ‰Û÷white‰Ûª and Latin lux ‰Û÷light‰Ûª
early 20th century; earliest use found in The Frederick Post. From light + speed
late 19th century; earliest use found in The Newark Advocate
late Middle English (in the senses ‰Û÷subject to Mars's influence‰Ûª and ‰Û÷martial‰Ûª): from Latin Mars, Mart- (see Mars) + -ian
1970s: from the name of a character in A Trekkie's Tale (1973), a parody fan fiction story based on the US television series Star Trek
late Middle English (in the sense ‰Û÷womb‰Ûª): from Latin, ‰Û÷breeding female‰Ûª, later ‰Û÷womb‰Ûª, from mater, matr- ‰Û÷mother‰Ûª
1970s; earliest use found in Public Opinion Quarterly
late Middle English (in mundane (sense 2)): from Old French mondain, from late Latin mundanus, from Latin mundus ‰Û÷world‰Ûª. mundane (sense 1) dates from the late 19th century
early 20th century: from Latin mutant- ‰Û÷changing‰Ûª, from the verb mutare
late Middle English: from Latin mutatio(n-), from mutare ‰Û÷to change‰Ûª
1990s; earliest use found in Cinefantastique. From nano- + -ite
mid 17th century (as a medical term): from Latin, literally ‰Û÷mist‰Ûª
Old English n‚£dl, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch naald and German Nadel, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin nere ‰Û÷to spin‰Ûª and Greek n€Òma ‰Û÷thread‰Ûª
mid 19th century: from Greek neuron in the sense ‰Û÷nerve‰Ûª + -al
1949: the name of an artificial official language in George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-Four
late 19th century: from Latin, feminine of novus ‰Û÷new‰Ûª (because such stars were thought to be newly formed)
1949: from George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-Four (see newspeak)
mid 16th century (referring to the eye socket): probably from medieval Latin orbitalis, from Latin orbita (see orbit)
1930s. From para- + human. Compare earlier superhuman [noun], subhuman, extra-human
1950s; earliest use found in Robert A. Heinlein (1907‰ÛÒ1988), writer

early 17th century: from Latin planum ‰Û÷flat surface‰Ûª, neuter of the adjective planus ‰Û÷plain‰Ûª. The adjective was suggested by French plan(e) ‰Û÷flat‰Ûª. The word was introduced to differentiate the geometrical senses, previously expressed by plain, from the latter's other meanings
1940s: from planet + -fall, on the pattern of landfall
mid 18th century; earliest use found in Benjamin Martin (bap. 1705, d. 1782), lecturer on science and maker of scientific instruments. From planet + -ography

1970s; earliest use found in The Washington Post. From pod + person, with allusion to the ‰Û÷seed pods‰Ûª in Jack Finney's novel The Body Snatchers, or any of several film adaptations based on this, in which the pods replicate and replace the population of a town
1940s; earliest use found in Isaac Asimov (1920‰ÛÒ1992), writer. From positron + -ic, after electronic
1950s; earliest use found in Philip K. Dick (1928‰ÛÒ1982), author. Shortened from either precognition or precognitive; apparently coined by Philip K. Dick
1940s; earliest use found in The Washington Post
1940s; earliest use found in Planet Stories. From pro + -zine
1950s: from psi, on the pattern of electronic
mid 19th century: abbreviation of public house
Middle English: from Old Norse reisa; related to the verb rear
Middle English: from Old French rai, based on Latin radius ‰Û÷spoke, ray‰Ûª. The verb dates from the late 16th century
from replica + -ant: first used in the film Blade Runner (1982)
1920s: from Czech, from robota ‰Û÷forced labour‰Ûª. The term was coined in K. €Îapek's play R.U.R ‰Û÷Rossum's Universal Robots‰Ûª (1920)
late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin sapient- ‰Û÷being wise‰Ûª, from the verb sapere
late 18th century; earliest use found in Isaac D'Israeli (1766‰ÛÒ1848), writer
early 20th century: blend of scientific and fiction
mid 17th century: via Latin from Greek sel€Ònit€Òs lithos ‰Û÷moonstone‰Ûª, from sel€Òn€Ò ‰Û÷moon‰Ûª + lithos ‰Û÷stone‰Ûª
early 17th century: from Latin sentient- ‰Û÷feeling‰Ûª, from the verb sentire
Old English scild (noun), scildan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch schild and German Schild, from a base meaning ‰Û÷divide, separate‰Ûª
Old English scip (noun), late Old English scipian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch schip and German Schiff
late Old English scipere ‰Û÷sailor‰Ûª. Current senses date from the mid 18th century

Old English scytel ‰Û÷dart, missile‰Ûª, of Germanic origin; compare with Old Norse skutill ‰Û÷harpoon‰Ûª; related to shoot. Sense 1 and the verb are from the movement of the bobbin from one side of the loom to the other and back
Middle English: from Old French singularite, from late Latin singularitas, from singularis ‰Û÷alone (of its kind)‰Ûª (see singular)
Middle English: from Old French escumoir, from escumer ‰Û÷skim‰Ûª, from escume ‰Û÷scum‰Ûª
1950s; earliest use found in The Chicago Sunday Tribune
late Middle English: perhaps imitative, or from Old French esclachier ‰Û÷break in pieces‰Ûª. The noun dates from the late 16th century
1980s: origin uncertain, but often interpreted as a shortening of smegma; first used on the British television series Red Dwarf
Middle English: shortening of Old French espace, from Latin spatium. Current verb senses date from the late 17th century
1970s; earliest use found in Arthur C. Clarke (1917‰ÛÒ2008), writer of science fiction
1950s; earliest use found in Space Science Fiction
early 20th century; earliest use found in Modern Electrics
late 19th century; earliest use found in Scribner's Monthly. From space + -ward
1930s. From space + -worthy, after airworthy and seaworthy

Middle English (denoting a flag raised on a pole as a rallying point, the authorized exemplar of a unit of measurement, or an upright timber): shortening of Old French estendart, from estendre ‰Û÷extend‰Ûª; in standard (sense 4 of the noun, standard sense 5 of the noun, standard sense 6 of the noun), influenced by the verb stand
from the title of the popular science fiction film Star Wars (1977)

from The Stepford Wives, the title of a 1972 novel by the American writer Ira Levin (1929‰ÛÒ2007), in which Stepford is the name of a fictional idyllic suburb where the men have replaced their wives with robots
1930s; earliest use found in Wonder Stories
1930s; earliest use found in Wonder Stories
1960s. From the genitive of the name of Theodore H. Sturgeon, U.S. science fiction writer + law

Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French siwte, from a feminine past participle of a Romance verb based on Latin sequi ‰Û÷follow‰Ûª. Early senses included ‰Û÷attendance at a court‰Ûª and ‰Û÷legal process‰Ûª; suit (sense 1 of the noun and suit sense 2 of the noun) derive from an earlier meaning ‰Û÷set of things to be used together‰Ûª. The verb sense ‰Û÷make appropriate‰Ûª dates from the late 16th century

the name (said to be an acronym of time and relative dimensions in space) of a time machine which had the exterior of a police telephone box in the British TV science fiction series Doctor Who, first broadcast in 1963
1950s: back-formation from teleportation ( 1930s), from tele- ‰Û÷at a distance‰Ûª + a shortened form of transportation
1940s; earliest use found in The Hartford Courant. From teleport + -er
mid 19th century: from Latin tellus, tellur- ‰Û÷earth‰Ûª + -ian

late Middle English; earliest use found in John Lydgate (c1370‰ÛÒc1449), poet and prior of Hatfield Regis. From classical Latin tellÇs earth, ground, also personified as a goddess, planet earth from the same Indo-European base as theal
1940s: from Latin terra ‰Û÷earth‰Ûª + the verb form
Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French, from Latin terrenus, from terra ‰Û÷earth‰Ûª
late Middle English (in the sense ‰Û÷temporal, worldly, mundane‰Ûª): from Latin terrestris (from terra ‰Û÷earth‰Ûª) + -al

Middle English: from Old French torche, from Latin torqua, variant of torques ‰Û÷necklace, wreath‰Ûª, from torquere ‰Û÷to twist‰Ûª. The current verb sense was originally US slang and dates from the 1930s
late 18th century (in the general sense ‰Û÷someone or something that pulls‰Ûª): from Latin, from tract- ‰Û÷pulled‰Ûª, from the verb trahere
coined by John Wyndham in Day of the Triffids (1951)
late Middle English: from Old French univers or Latin universum, neuter of universus ‰Û÷combined into one, whole‰Ûª, from uni- ‰Û÷one‰Ûª + versus ‰Û÷turned‰Ûª (past participle of vertere)
1949: coined by George Orwell in the novel Nineteen Eighty-Four
mid 16th century: based on Greek ou ‰Û÷not‰Ûª + topos ‰Û÷place‰Ûª; the word was first used in the book Utopia (1516) by Sir Thomas More
Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French vessel(e), from late Latin vascellum, diminutive of vas ‰Û÷vessel‰Ûª

late Middle English (denoting the venom of a snake): from Latin, literally ‰Û÷slimy liquid, poison‰Ûª. The earlier medical sense, superseded by the current use as a result of improved scientific understanding, was ‰Û÷a substance produced in the body as the result of disease, especially one capable of infecting others‰Ûª
1940s: named after Waldo F. Jones, a fictional inventor described by Robert Heinlein in a science fiction story

Old English weorpan (verb), wearp (noun), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch werpen and German werfen ‰Û÷to throw‰Ûª. Early verb senses included ‰Û÷throw‰Ûª and ‰Û÷hit with a missile‰Ûª; the sense ‰Û÷bend‰Ûª dates from late Middle English. The noun was originally a term in weaving (see warp (sense 2 of the noun))
1970s: popularized by the US television series Star Trek (originally referring to a faster-than-light speed attained by a spaceship travelling in a space warp)
1990s: from web, in the sense ‰Û÷World Wide Web‰Ûª, and broadcast
mid 19th century; earliest use found in Martin Tupper (1810‰ÛÒ1889), poet and writer. From world + -let
Old English wyrm (noun), of Germanic origin; related to Latin vermis ‰Û÷worm‰Ûª and Greek rhomox ‰Û÷woodworm‰Ûª
1950s; earliest use found in Robert A. Heinlein (1907‰ÛÒ1988), writer
